channel.title: software engineering on Yanir Seroussi | Data & AI for Nature
channel.description: Recent content in software engineering on Yanir Seroussi | Data & AI for Nature
channel.copyright: Text and figures licensed under [CC BY-NC-ND 4.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/) by [Yanir Seroussi](https://yanirseroussi.com/about/), except where noted otherwise  |

item.title: Supporting volunteer monitoring of marine biodiversity with modern web and data tools
item.description: Summarising the work Uri Seroussi and I did to improve Reef Life Survey’s Reef Species of the World app.

item.title: You don't need a proprietary API for static maps
item.description: For many use cases, libraries like cartopy are better than the likes of Mapbox and Google Maps.

item.title: Lessons from reluctant data engineering
item.description: Video and summary of a talk I gave at DataEngBytes Brisbane on what I learned from doing data engineering as part of every data science role I had.

item.title: Google's Rules of Machine Learning still apply in the age of large language models
item.description: Despite the excitement around large language models, building with machine learning remains an engineering problem with established best practices.

item.title: Was data science a failure mode of software engineering?
item.description: Yes, data science projects have suffered from classic software engineering mistakes, but the field is maturing with the rise of new engineering roles.

item.title: How hackable are automated coding assessments?
item.description: Exploring the hackability of speed-based coding tests, using CodeSignal’s Industry Coding Framework as a case study.

item.title: Building useful machine learning tools keeps getting easier: A fish ID case study
item.description: Lessons learned building a fish ID web app with fast.ai and Streamlit, in an attempt to reduce my fear of missing out on the latest deep learning developments.

item.title: My work with Automattic
item.description: Back-dated meta-post that gathers my posts on Automattic blogs into a summary of the work I’ve done with the company.

item.title: Software commodities are eating interesting data science work
item.description: Being a data scientist can sometimes feel like a race against software commodities that replace interesting work. What can one do to remain relevant?

item.title: Bootstrapping the right way?
item.description: Video and summary of a talk I gave at YOW! Data on bootstrap estimation of confidence intervals.

item.title: Hackers beware: Bootstrap sampling may be harmful
item.description: Bootstrap sampling has been promoted as an easy way of modelling uncertainty to hackers without much statistical knowledge. But things aren’t that simple.

item.title: Exploring and visualising Reef Life Survey data
item.description: Web tools I built to visualise Reef Life Survey data and assist citizen scientists in underwater visual census work.

item.title: Is Data Scientist a useless job title?
item.description: It seems like anyone who touches data can call themselves a data scientist, which makes the title useless. The work they do can still be useful, though.

item.title: Migrating a simple web application from MongoDB to Elasticsearch
item.description: Migrating BCRecommender from MongoDB to Elasticsearch made it possible to offer a richer search experience to users at a similar cost, among other benefits.

item.title: The wonderful world of recommender systems
item.description: Giving an overview of the field and common paradigms, and debunking five common myths about recommender systems.

item.title: Goodbye, Parse.com
item.description: Migrating my web apps away from Parse.com due to reliability issues. Self-hosting is a better solution.

item.title: First steps in data science: author-aware sentiment analysis
item.description: I became a data scientist by doing a PhD, but the same steps can be followed without a formal education program.

item.title: Automating Parse.com bulk data imports
item.description: A script for importing data into the Parse backend-as-a-service.

item.title: What is data science?
item.description: Data science has been a hot term in the past few years. Still, there isn’t a single definition of the field. This post discusses my favourite definition.

item.title: Building a recommender system on a shoestring budget (or: BCRecommender part 2 – general system layout)
item.description: Iterating on my BCRecommender service with the goal of keeping costs low while providing a valuable music recommendation service.
